page.title: 07FARMING: LIVESTOCK
page.content: There are two Friesian milking herds in our area (see next page), one on a farm -largely outside our block- which also keeps pigs; several farms fatten up one or two dozen beef cattle. Three farms keep{Sheep.}One, with about 370 crossbred "mule" ewes, a few pure Suffolk ewes, and 12 tups, prod- uces 600 lambs for meat. The ewes are tupped in October; lambs are born in February and March and go to market from the end of May onwards. Sheep, dipped twice a year for scab and foot rot, are sheared in June. Turnips are grown to supplement their winter diet. Another farm has about 150 mules, a few Suffolk/Border Leicester ewes and 5 Suffolk tups. About 260 lambs, born in March/April, are sold in autumn. The farm also rears 30-40 beef cattle, Hereford/Friesian cross or Charolais. The third has a few Welsh Blacks.
